titlestmt.subtitle: An inventory of Washington Women's Arts Center at DC Public Library
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Leroy Graham/Fay Haskins.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-03-26 13:24:11 -0400.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Two events in metropolitan Washington, D.C. area were the primary catalysts for the Washington Women's Arts Center -- The Conference of Women in the Visual Arts held April 20-22, 1972 at the Corcoran Gallery; and Womansphere, an arts festival held at Glen Echo Park, Maryland in 1974. The Conference attracted significant women artists from around the country, including Elaine deKooning, Katherine Anne Porter, Lois M. Jones, and Judy Chicago. The conference steering committee consisted of Mary Beth Edelson, Cynthia Bickley-Green, Barbara Frank, Enid Sandford, Susan Sollins, Josephine Withers, and Yvonne Wulf. Participants were concerned about the presentation and involvement of so few women artists in the Corcoran's Biennial Exhibition and other exhibitions at major U.S. art galleries. As a result of these events, local women who attended began discussing and planning for a D.C. women arts center.

The Center was established in 1975 to provide a place for Washington, D.C. women to show their work, improve their artistic skills, and develop their artistic professionalism. The original founders included Barbara Frank, Katherine Butler, Janis Goodman, Sarah Hyde, and Ann Slayton-Leffler. The site of the first Center was in a renovated basement at 1821 Q Street, N.W. The Center sponsored a monthly series of lectures and published a journal, Womansphere. It also conducted workshops, and held literary readings, live performances, and gallery talks. The primary concentration of the Center was sponsoring juried exhibits of local women artists. In 1983 the Center moved to the Lansburgh Cultural Center. The Center closed in the late 1980s.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The records were donated by Marcia Pemberton and Pamela Brown, members of the Washington Women's Arts Center in 1989.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains general administrative files that include correspondence, Board meeting minutes, annuals reports, contracts, insurance policies, and grant files. A substantial amount of financial documentation such as Center budgets, receipts, ledgers, financial statements, deposit sheets, and cash books. Also contains records which document the Center's history and membership such as guest books, membership directories, and documentation of the Women's Conference in the Visual Arts of 1972. Publications such as Womensphere, the Center's published journal, and issues of its newsletter are included. Contains records documenting exhibits mounted at the Center such as exhibition lists, resumes, printed programs, and publicity materials. Also contains audiovisual materials, including audio recordings, video recordings, slides, and photographs of events and exhibits at the Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence and financial documents relating to the Women's Conference in the Visual Arts of 1972. Also contains correspondence and other items regarding the first site location, early publicity, proposals, and studies to establish the Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains the Center's Board of Directors meeting minutes, annual reports, incorporation papers, and by-laws of the Center. Projected budgets from 1978 through 1987 are also among the records.

did.unittitle: Coalition of Women's Art Organization Membership

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, memoranda, brochures, press releases, and reports regarding such topics as government and foundation grants, publicity, elections, Center workshops, the Lansburgh Center move, and the Edith C. Blum lecture series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, budgets, ledgers, receipts, insurance policies, financial statements, gallery cash daybook, and other financial information. The records also cover grants from the D.C. Government and the National Education Association.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains records which document individuals which supported and attended the Center's activities, including membership directories, guest books for Center events, an address book (1980), card index of active members (1987), and cards index of inactive members (1988).

scopecontent.p: Exhibition office files which contain correspondence, handwritten lists, contracts, clippings, publicity, some photographs, and resumes between the Center and the artist as well as others involved in planning for exhibitions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Loose-leaf notebooks of all final documentation on each exhibit. They contain photographs, correspondence, resumes, lists of items in exhibitions, slides, and clips from the publications, including the Center's newsletter, Womansphere, and Artist Outreach.
